items.title:
For AI to be truly useful, it needs to understand you. 
With Personal Intelligence, we‚Äôre beginning ...
items.content:
For AI to be truly useful, it needs to understand you. 
With Personal Intelligence, we‚Äôre beginning to solve this. With your permission, Gemini can now securely reason across your own data to answer questions that generic models simply can't - like suggesting plans based on travel dates in Gmail or your hobbies found in Photos. An exciting step towards a digital assistant that‚Äôs uniquely helpful to you.
items.author: @demishassabis
items.summary: Demis Hassabis announces 'Personal Intelligence' - Gemini can now securely reason across user's personal data (Gmail, Photos) with permission to provide personalized assistance like travel planning.

items.title:
evals should be validated by vibes.

i think not enough people give sufficient credit to @METR_Evals...
items.content:
evals should be validated by vibes.

i think not enough people give sufficient credit to @METR_Evals (@joel_bkr et al) for clearly identifying/quantifying the Opus 4.5 outperformance.

on paper, GPT 5.2 Thinking outperforms Opus 4.5 by 55.6 vs 52% on SWE Bench Pro.

in practice METR's long evals benchmark, while getting increasingly sparse in the long tail, clearly called out the huge jump that many devs are now experiencing a month later. in fact it is such an outlier that the curve fit was probably wrong/needs to be restarted as a new epoch.

do see his @aiDotEngineer talk on the eval https://t.co/n1JxxNE3az and we are releasing his 2hr longer workshop on how it works next week as our last release of AIE CODE before we prep for AIE Europe.
items.author: @swyx
items.summary: swyx argues evals should be validated by vibes. Credits METR for identifying Opus 4.5's outperformance over GPT 5.2 Thinking on long-horizon tasks despite GPT leading on SWE Bench Pro (55.6% vs 52%). Notes Opus 4.5 performance is such an outlier it may represent a new epoch.
items.reasoning: High-value analysis from credible source. Highlights disconnect between benchmark scores and real-world developer experience. Significant claim that Opus 4.5 represents paradigm shift. High engagement (218 likes, 22k views).

items.title: Teaching an experimental class for MBAs on ‚Äúvibefounding,‚Äù the students have four days to come up an...
items.content:
Teaching an experimental class for MBAs on ‚Äúvibefounding,‚Äù the students have four days to come up and launch a company. More on this eventually, but quick observations:

1) I have taught entrepreneurship for over a decade. Everything they are doing in four days would have taken a semester in previous years, if it could have done it at all. Quality is also far better.

2) Give people tools and training and they can do amazing things. We are using a combination of Claude Code, Gemini, and ChatGPT. The non-coders are all building working products. But also everyone is doing weeks of high quality work on financials, research, pricing, positioning, marketing in hours. All the tools are weird to use, even with some training, but they are figuring it out.

3) People with experience in an industry or skill have a huge advantage as they can build solutions that have built-in markets & which solve known hard problems that seemed impossible. (Always been true, but the barriers have fallen to actually doing stuff)

4) The hardest thing to get across is that AI doesn‚Äôt just do work for you, it also does new kinds of work. The most successful efforts often take advantage of the fact that the AI itself is very smart. How do you bring its analytical, creative, and empathetic abilities to bear on a problem? What do you do with access to a very smart intelligence on demand?

I wish I had more frameworks to clearly teach. So many assumptions about how to launch a business have clearly changed. You don‚Äôt need to go through the same discovery process if you build a dozen ideas at the same time & get AI feedback. Many, many new possibilities, and the students really see how big a deal this is.

Companies that are the furthest from AI‚Äîlike travel and experiences‚Äîare quite interesting in a world with lots of AI, although I am also sure bringing AI to Airbnb will make it much better.

items.title: Two agentic-coding chatbots: Claude and ChatGPT. Both can take a zip file with an app, fix it, and r...
items.content:
Two agentic-coding chatbots: Claude and ChatGPT. Both can take a zip file with an app, fix it, and return the fixed zip back.

Claude: fast and effective.

ChatGPT: slow and less effective.

Why?

Observe the way they work with the codebase. Claude uses Linux file search commands to find relevant pieces in the codebase:

grep -r -C 10 -e "keyword1" -e "keyword2" -e "keyword3" /path/to/directory/with/the/app

-r ‚Äî recursive search

-C 10 ‚Äî show 10 lines of context before and after each match

where keywords 1-3 are generated by the LLM based on the bug description. Once the matches are found, Claude has potentially relevant code snippets and then digs deeper starting from these snippets.

ChatGPT apparently uses code embeddings to find relevant code files and then uses a fixed window scanning approach: "Let me see the first 400 lines of code, now let me see the next 400 lines, ...". This is why it's very slow and inefficient.

The fact that ChatGPT uses 400 (a round number and not something learned like 376.4) as a window size makes one think that this scanning approach was human-built rather than learned.

Claude was definitely given a list of Linux commands it can use, such as grep, and then finetuned using RL to use these Linux commands to fix a certain synthetic problem.

Also, Claude was instructed to generate disposable scripts (and run them in a runtime) that reproduce only a certain chain of dependencies from the entire application by abstracting out irrelevant parts of the full app code.

This allows recreating, in a tiny script, how the signal of interest passes through the app from input to output without running the full app and see where it gets corrupted. Claude learned to generate such simulated dependency chains and use the result to decide whether the chain needs to be updated and run again or the problem is clear now.

If the problem was fixed, Claude got a positive reward. Otherwise, the reward was negative. So, the entire process can be trained end to end as a regular LLM finetuning.

Other companies, I'm sure, have already reverse-engineered Claude Code in much better detail than I and understand what needs to be done to catch up with Anthropic.

I expect all major players to have an agentic coding system trained end-to-end by the end of the first quarter of 2026.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Andriy Burkov provides detailed technical analysis comparing Claude Code vs ChatGPT agentic coding: Claude uses grep/Linux commands and disposable scripts for dependency chains; ChatGPT uses slower embedding-based search with fixed 400-line windows.
items.reasoning: Rare technical reverse-engineering of Claude Code's approach vs competitors. Actionable insights for practitioners. Predicts all major players will have end-to-end trained agentic coding by Q1 2026.
items.summary_html: Andriy Burkov provides detailed technical analysis comparing Claude Code vs ChatGPT agentic coding: Claude uses grep/Linux commands and disposable scripts for dependency chains; ChatGPT uses slower embedding-based search with fixed 400-line windows.

items.title:
OK, I've got Claude Cowork feedback. 

TLDR - there are many things that I love about it, but even a...
items.content:
OK, I've got Claude Cowork feedback. 

TLDR - there are many things that I love about it, but even as a non-engineer, I will be sticking to Claude Code for now. I suspect Anthropic is doubling down hard on this and I will make the switch to Cowork in a month. 

One, Claude Cowork should not be advertised as "Claude Code for Business Users". Majority of business users have no idea what Claude Code is. They have no reference. Marketing needs to be relevant. 

Two, capability discovery is hell. I love the "let's knock something off your list" (whoever wrote that - you are smart and I like you). But I don't want to organize files. And prepping for the day doesn't work/gives too strange of a readout/didn't prompt to connect to gcal and instead opened claude for chrome to slowly navigate my whole calendar for the next day. Make it more obvious what advanced things I can do that make me say WOW. 

Third, speaking of, I wish the wow features were given more weight. I have now demoed Claude Cowork to tons of non-technical people. I know what stands out. Do you know how much of an 'OH MY GOD' I hear when I show that you can queue up tasks? Or that you can stack tasks (like compare these two docs, create a summary, save the summary to my desktop, and then draft an email with that summary in old english)? And even save those tasks to come back to them over and over and over again? Add a widget on the right for the queue. Add a proactive layer. 

Fourth, multitasking is bigger than people realize. Saw someone from Anthropic say they have 3-8 Claude instances running at once. I really liked the Convergence AI interface for this. Sort of similar (though not as fun as) @emollick experiment with the multi-agent office animation. Stop it with the chat threads. Help me do multi-threaded work. 

That being said, they made it in a week and a half. AI coded the whole thing. The team cooked and @mikeyk moving over is going to be great. Anthropic is having quite a run. Can't wait for the updates to roll out and extend beyond Max accounts.
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Detailed user feedback on Claude Cowork: praises task queuing but criticizes capability discovery, marketing, and suggests improvements for multitasking UI. Notes it was built in 1.5 weeks with AI coding.

items.title:
Announcing Personal Intelligence, a more personalized @GeminiApp designed just for you.

How it work...
items.content:
Announcing Personal Intelligence, a more personalized @GeminiApp designed just for you.

How it works:
‚Äî Customized: With your permission, it reasons across your @Gmail, @YouTube, @GooglePhotos, and Search apps to share hyper-relevant and context-aware responses
‚Äî Secure: If enabled, you control which Google apps to connect to. This setting is off by default
‚Äî Useful: From travel plans based on your Google Photos to gym recommendations based on goals you‚Äôve shared with Gemini, you get help tailored to your world

Personal Intelligence in beta is rolling out to Google AI Pro and AI Ultra subscribers in the U.S., with expansions to the free tier, more countries, and AI Mode in Search to come. Take a look at the Gemini app's personalized assistance in the clip below, then let us know what you would use it for!
items.author: @GoogleAI
items.summary: Google AI official announcement of Personal Intelligence beta - customized Gemini that reasons across Gmail, YouTube, Photos with user permission. Rolling out to AI Pro/Ultra subscribers in US.
items.reasoning: Official detailed announcement of major Gemini feature. High engagement (260k views). Includes specific rollout details and privacy controls.
items.summary_html: Google AI official announcement of Personal Intelligence beta - customized Gemini that reasons across Gmail, YouTube, Photos with user permission. Rolling out to AI Pro/Ultra subscribers in US.
items.content_html:
Announcing Personal Intelligence, a more personalized @GeminiApp designed just for you.

How it works:

‚Äî Customized: With your permission, it reasons across your @Gmail, @YouTube, @GooglePhotos, and Search apps to share hyper-relevant and context-aware responses

‚Äî Secure: If enabled, you control which Google apps to connect to. This setting is off by default

‚Äî Useful: From travel plans based on your Google Photos to gym recommendations based on goals you‚Äôve shared with Gemini, you get help tailored to your world

Personal Intelligence in beta is rolling out to Google AI Pro and AI Ultra subscribers in the U.S., with expansions to the free tier, more countries, and AI Mode in Search to come. Take a look at the Gemini app's personalized assistance in the clip below, then let us know what you would use it for!

items.title:
We've built a massive verification bottleneck:

‚Ä¢ 72% of developers use AI to generate code every da...
items.content:
We've built a massive verification bottleneck:

‚Ä¢ 72% of developers use AI to generate code every day
‚Ä¢ 96% of them don't fully trust it

Writing code is now free. All the work now is verifying that the code does what it's supposed to.

According to a new State of Code Survey, almost half of the respondents believe the number one skill that will matter most in the coming years is "reviewing and validating AI-generated code for quality and security".

Not prompt engineering or vibe-coding, but checking AI's work.

items.title: @ChrisMGreer I get better results doing regression, but using SGD instead of Adam on the final linea...
items.content: @ChrisMGreer I get better results doing regression, but using SGD instead of Adam on the final linear layer so it is ‚Äúscale invariant‚Äù with respect to the value functions. Adam‚Äôs gradient normalization makes it bad at modeling values that differ by orders of magnitude. SGD doesn‚Äôt care if your scores are coming in 1s or 10_000s.

items.title: New course: Document AI: From OCR to Agentic Doc Extraction, built with @LandingAI, where I'm execut...
items.content:
New course: Document AI: From OCR to Agentic Doc Extraction, built with @LandingAI, where I'm executive chairman, and taught by David Park and Andrea Kropp.

Much of the world's data is locked in PDFs, JPEGs, and other documents. This short course shows you how to build agentic workflows that process documents accurately: breaking them into parts, examining each piece carefully, and extracting information through multiple iterations.

Traditional Optical Character Recognition (OCR) captures text but loses context from table headers, chart captions, or reading order of columns. After exploring OCR's limitations, you‚Äôll use LandingAI's Agentic Document Extraction (ADE) framework to process documents. ADE treats pages as visually -- as images -- to parse information and extract fields.

Skills you'll gain:
- Build agents to convert unstructured files into structured Markdown/HTML and JSON
- Use ADE to parse complex data like forms, handwriting, or equations
- Map extracted information to named fields using a specified schema, with bounding boxes for grounding and validation
- Deploy RAG applications with event-driven document processing

Come learn about the best tools for processing documents like financial invoices, medical records, or academic papers intelligently: 
https://t.co/PYjgnoaD2K
items.author: @AndrewYNg
items.summary: Andrew Ng announces new Document AI course covering agentic workflows for document extraction - moving beyond OCR limitations to visual document parsing with LandingAI's ADE framework.
items.reasoning: Educational content from highly influential AI educator. Practical skills for enterprise AI applications. Document processing is major enterprise use case. 149k views.

items.title:
You'll find way more information in Sonar's State of Code report (linked below):

‚Ä¢ 1,100 developers...
items.content:
You'll find way more information in Sonar's State of Code report (linked below):

‚Ä¢ 1,100 developers.
‚Ä¢ 42% of their committed code is now AI-assisted.
‚Ä¢ They predict this will hit 65% by 2027.
‚Ä¢ 61% of developers think AI produces code that isn't reliable.

Here is an even better one:

38% of developers say reviewing AI-generated code takes more effort than reviewing code written by a colleague.

The kicker:

Developers are still spending the same amount of time reviewing code as they did writing it. There's no decrease in work toil at all.

We didn't eliminate the grunt work.
We traded one kind for another.

This is pretty inline with my experience.

AI is a force multiplier, not a replacement for judgment.

The report is worth reading if you want to understand what's really happening beyond the hype:

https://t.co/8Gb4IgtqsU

@yoheinakajima We implemented our own Search Tool here because the CC code is all client-side.

Basi...
items.author: @trq212
items.summary: Claude Code team member explains custom Search Tool implementation: keyword-based similarity search returning tool names, agent can do parallel/multiple searches. All client-side code
items.reasoning: Technical deep-dive from Claude Code team on tool search implementation. Very high views (40k) for a reply. Valuable for understanding how CC handles large tool sets
items.summary_html: Claude Code team member explains custom Search Tool implementation: keyword-based similarity search returning tool names, agent can do parallel/multiple searches. All client-side code
items.content_html:
@yoheinakajima We implemented our own Search Tool here because the CC code is all client-side.

Basically it's a regular tool, it takes in a keyword and does a similarity search on it to return a list of tool names. Since it's just a tool in the agent loop Claude can then search other keywords or do parallel calls with multiple keywords.

lmk if that makes sense or if you have any other questions

items.title:
Robot companies gas up. 

This shows that the rich people see a big new market coming.

Yesterday at...
items.content:
Robot companies gas up. 

This shows that the rich people see a big new market coming.

Yesterday at JPMorgan event happening in San Francisco, lots of VCs said they are making robots a bigger part of their business. 

Bets are being made, and it has impact on AI industry because talent will start flowing to the robot companies that have a shot at building robots for various needs. Skilld has some of the best AI I've seen, so this makes sense. 

I have a list of everyone in robotics: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ and separate lists of robot influencers and those who are just in San Francisco area. 

Will be interviewing more of these companies this year, and do more consumer research to figure out how they are looking at the market (and I'm looking forward to getting the @1x_tech NEO, coming later this year).

items.title:
I had an extraordinary day today! 

I met with the founders of GMI and Blackbox AI, talking to both ...
items.content:
I had an extraordinary day today! 

I met with the founders of GMI and Blackbox AI, talking to both about how deeply AI is changing how software is made and companies are built, but the highlight was attending Daniel Kraft's @daniel_kraft medical lunch, which was part of the J.P. Morgan event in San Francisco this week. A lot of rich people are in town for this event.

The networking was extraordinary:
1. I spent quite a bit of time with legendary investor Esther Dyson @edyson.
2. I saw a new kind of device that uses magnetic fields to change the cellular structure of your brain and get rid of inflammation.

You're going to hear a lot more about this device over the next year or two. 

It is helping with many people's pain and mental illnesses. 

It's just a stunning example of how people are able to discover new ways to help human beings with technology. I'll have a lot more to say when they come out of stealth.

San Francisco may someday fall into ruin. 

But not yet.

items.title: @tenobrus So skills, agents, etc. are a bit weird because they are not tools but instead parameters ...
items.author: @trq212
items.summary: Technical discussion on MCP architecture: skills and agents are parameters not tools, context management differs from MCP where users have less control over context size
items.reasoning: Technical insight from Anthropic employee on MCP vs skills/agents distinction. Explains why MCP context management is challenging compared to curated skills.
items.summary_html: Technical discussion on MCP architecture: skills and agents are parameters not tools, context management differs from MCP where users have less control over context size
items.content_html:
@tenobrus So skills, agents, etc. are a bit weird because they are not tools but instead parameters that the Skill and Agent tools can call with

It's not clear to me if there should be agent search, skill search, one unified search extension point or no such search.

I think what's unique about MCP is that you're not really in control of how much they put into context, whereas subagents and skills put roughly a constant amount of information in context so you can curate yourself a bit more (e.g. if you install 50 skills that's on you).

items.title: Super impressed by the projects at the Agentic Hackathon last weekend! Many teams work on really har...
items.content:
Super impressed by the projects at the Agentic Hackathon last weekend! Many teams work on really hard/important problems:

* Long running tasks: memory management, recovering from mid-task failures, and maintaining consistency across steps and sub-agents

* Adaptive retrieval from multiple sources: databases, search indices, and websites

* Agents that work with voice, video, and even 3D environments

If you are in SF, come check out the finalist demos tomorrow! https://t.co/JytAN5xqyG

There will be talks by Douglas Eck, who is doing amazing work with Veo and Imagen and many other awesome folks.

Thanks @MongoDB  and @cerebral_valley for hosting and for letting me serve as a judge for these fantastic projects.

items.summary_html: Chip Huyen highlights key challenges from Agentic Hackathon: long-running task memory, failure recovery, adaptive multi-source retrieval, and multimodal/3D agents
items.content_html:
Super impressed by the projects at the Agentic Hackathon last weekend! Many teams work on really hard/important problems:

* Long running tasks: memory management, recovering from mid-task failures, and maintaining consistency across steps and sub-agents

* Adaptive retrieval from multiple sources: databases, search indices, and websites

* Agents that work with voice, video, and even 3D environments

If you are in SF, come check out the finalist demos tomorrow! https://t.co/JytAN5xqyG

There will be talks by Douglas Eck, who is doing amazing work with Veo and Imagen and many other awesome folks.

Thanks @MongoDB and @cerebral_valley for hosting and for letting me serve as a judge for these fantastic projects.

items.title:
‚ú® Added a CRT curvature distortion to @pieter now

It takes the Em-DOSBox <canvas> and processes it ...
items.content:
‚ú® Added a CRT curvature distortion to @pieter now

It takes the Em-DOSBox <canvas> and processes it in WebGL and builds a new <canvas> with the distortion of a classic CRT screen which had this convex curvature (like an old TV) even though the screen itself was square

I had this working on DOSBox on MacOS and on Linux with CRT-Pi shader, but on web it doesn't support shaders so I had to build my own with Claude Code in JS, very easy

I remember trying this a year ago and Claude Code fucked it up so bad that I gave up, so I think the models have improved a lot

Tomorrow I'll try add some scanlines, it really helps make the simulation more passable (and nostalgic!) üòäüëå

items.title:
Vibe Coding Without System Design is a Trap: https://t.co/gAObv6Zrjk

TL;DR:  AI-assisted coding str...
items.content:
Vibe Coding Without System Design is a Trap: https://t.co/gAObv6Zrjk

TL;DR:  AI-assisted coding streamlines product creation but often sacrifices long-term design sustainability. It prioritizes immediate functionality, leading to hardcoded configurations, which are fragile for future updates. Successful product development requires experienced system design to avoid a "build-now, regret-later" scenario, which can then transform AI vibes into structured, sustainable solutions.

items.title:
Just implemented Code Sandbox for TypingMind ü•≥

I was looking at various options for sandbox and cod...
items.content:
Just implemented Code Sandbox for TypingMind ü•≥

I was looking at various options for sandbox and code execution, but for now the most obvious choice is to use the built-in sandbox provided by all popular providers: OpenAI/Gemini/Claude.

It can create files but not yet able to accept file input, except for OpenAI's API, which gives your 20 minutes of "persistent container" which persist the files and the execution session.

I'll look into implement 3rd party provided sandboxes like Vercel sandbox or E2B soon!

items.summary: Tony Dinh implements Code Sandbox for TypingMind using built-in sandbox from OpenAI/Gemini/Claude APIs. Notes OpenAI offers 20-min persistent containers. Plans to add Vercel/E2B sandboxes

items.title: What is needed for startups and medium-size tech companies to contribute to open science and open-so...
items.content:
What is needed for startups and medium-size tech companies to contribute to open science and open-source AI more?

When thinking about open-source, people usually think about big tech or academia but in my opinion, startups and medium-sized tech companies could be massive contributors and benefit a ton from sharing AI models, datasets, research,... (in terms of visibility, hiring, ability to transition into AI,...). 

We're seeing that a lot in China and looks like we might start to see it in the US too as showed by the fact that the two trending models on @huggingface have been from these types of orgs (@fal and @Lightricks). 

Also interesting that @Airbnb @bchesky hired @Ahmad_Al_Dahle (former Llama lead) maybe to do more of that?

items.summary: Clement Delangue asks what's needed for startups/mid-size companies to contribute more to open-source AI. Notes trend in China, mentions Ahmad's Airbnb hire potentially for this purpose.

items.title:
This is a major step toward holodecks, or, augmented reality, and virtual reality. 

It does have a ...
items.content:
This is a major step toward holodecks, or, augmented reality, and virtual reality. 

It does have a long way to go, though, to get to the promised land where we have a full-on, really great 3D environment that's built for us, interactive, and includes virtual beings. 

We're expecting the industry to be able to deliver that (or at least a good chunk of it) in the next 12 months. I think the next two years are going to be pretty stunning when this stuff starts really cooking. I'm so excited about world models and where they're going!

They have a long feature list that I've been talking with them about, and they're working on it now. I'd expect to see major advancements quite frequently as this year moves along.

items.title: Most AI systems that help with real-world tasks‚Äîlike guiding you through a recipe or telling a robot...
items.content:
Most AI systems that help with real-world tasks‚Äîlike guiding you through a recipe or telling a robot what to do next‚Äîeither learn by imitating human demonstrations or by trial-and-error in simulated environments.

The first approach copies whatever humans did, including their mistakes, and can't reason about whether an action is actually good. The second requires building simulations for every domain you care about, which doesn't scale.

This paper proposes a different approach: Train a "world model" that predicts what happens when you take an action, then use that model to mentally simulate different plans and pick the best one.

Previous world models (like the one I posted about two weeks ago https://t.co/LkmYrgel1p) typically predict future video frames, which is computationally expensive and wastes effort on irrelevant visual details. This paper instead predicts future states in natural language‚Äîso instead of generating pixels showing a pan heating up, the model outputs text describing that the pan is now hot and ready for cooking. This makes the predictions interpretable and cheap to generate.

The authors then train a separate "critic" model that scores how close a predicted trajectory is to achieving a goal, using self-supervised signals. At inference time, the system can either generate a single plan quickly, or generate multiple candidate plans, simulate their outcomes, and select the one the critic scores best.

The approach is trained on about 180,000 instructional and egocentric videos, and when humans are asked to compare its plans against those from large language models or ground-truth annotations, they consistently prefer the plans from this system.

Read with an AI tutor: https://t.co/cRGJwN84FB

Read alone: https://t.co/fHof1qmwO0
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explains paper on world models that predict future states in natural language rather than video frames, enabling efficient action planning for real-world tasks.
items.reasoning: Technical paper explanation on important research direction (world models). Educational content from ML author.

items.title: The *Hundred-Page Language Models Book* by Andriy Burkov is a good one. It's a hands-on, mathematica...
items.content:
The *Hundred-Page Language Models Book* by Andriy Burkov is a good one. It's a hands-on, mathematically honest introduction to language models that takes you from n-grams through RNNs to Transformers, culminating in practical LLM work (prompting, finetuning). You code a Transformer from scratch in PyTorch. All examples run on Google Colab.

Strengths: Burkov's signature compression‚Äîdense without being shallow. Unlike most "accessible" books that strip out the math to seem friendly, he keeps it, because the math is the understanding. You walk away knowing why things work, not just that they work.

The pedagogical arc is unusually well-designed. Rather than dumping Transformers on you in chapter one (the approach most LLM content takes), he builds incrementally: count-based methods ‚Üí neural language models ‚Üí RNNs ‚Üí attention ‚Üí Transformers ‚Üí LLMs. Each layer of complexity earns its place because you understand what problem it solves.

It's genuinely hands-on. You implement three different language model architectures yourself. The Transformer isn't a black box you import‚Äîyou build it. This kind of "from scratch" work cements intuition in ways that reading alone never does.

The endorsements aren't empty marketing. Tom√°≈° Mikolov (word2vec, FastText) wrote the foreword. Vint Cerf called it "a gem of clarity." These are people who would know if the technical content were sloppy.

Finally, it respects your time. In an era of bloated 600-page textbooks and endless video courses, getting a complete mental model of language models in a weekend of focused reading is genuinely valuable.

Who it's for: Technical professionals‚Äîdevelopers, data scientists, ML engineers‚Äîwho want to understand the internals rather than just call APIs. Not for complete beginners to programming or math.

Bottom line: If you appreciated his ML book's ethos (concise, rigorous, practical), this delivers the same for the LLM era. It won't make you a researcher, but it'll give you genuine mechanical understanding of how these models work.

#LMtrainingData

items.title:
@ASychov I agree with you. This will force VR to survive on its own.

There is a new VR coming. I sa...
items.content:
@ASychov I agree with you. This will force VR to survive on its own.

There is a new VR coming. I saw glimmers of it at CES this year with pretty nice displays and lightweight glasses. We can certainly see that in two years, you are going to get very capable, lightweight displays.

This will be joined with world models which are going to create Gaussian splats, a new kind of holodeck. When we get into that world (two, three, or four years from now), then we will see a new VR:
1. One that is cheaper to create for content creators
2. One that is more fun to play for consumers

Then we will see where we are, but it is going to take a while to get into this new VR. I call it the holodeck.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Predicts new VR era in 2-4 years featuring lightweight displays, world models, and Gaussian splats creating 'holodeck' experiences that are cheaper to create and more fun

items.title: @SnappyBiscuit2 There's a lot of truth to what you say; it's got me thinking, and it's hard to argue...
items.content:
@SnappyBiscuit2 There's a lot of truth to what you say; it's got me thinking, and it's hard to argue with. I think the whole platform was not well thought through, and they made a lot of mistakes along the way.

For instance:
1. They threw a Super Bowl promotion but couldn't get more than 15,000 people into the concert they were advertising.
2. They failed to provide the right content for the hardware. In a lot of ways, you're right‚Äîthey needed a good AAA game.

This is actually something that bums me out about Meta's Ray-Ban smart glasses (the ones with the display). There's only one video game on them! It's like, you guys spent how many billions of dollars and you only got one video game?

You went too far the other way. You should have had a whole bunch of casual titles, like Angry Birds and Words with Friends. Something is just wrong with this team.

I hear from people inside and outside that it's a really bad culture in terms of getting people to work on a very innovative product and have big breakthroughs. A lot of the blame goes straight to Zuckerberg.

The truth is, most of the executives at Meta joined the company when they were very young. At that time, 3D computing didn't exist, so there are a lot of "2D thinkers" who struggle to get into spatial computing. I've heard that from many people both inside the team and out.

It's a tough situation. It's just going to take more time for this whole field to mature to a place where consumers see a huge amount of value in wearing a pair of glasses that have a lot of technology in them.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer critiques Meta's VR strategy: Super Bowl promo failure, lack of games on Ray-Ban display glasses, internal culture problems with '2D thinkers'
items.reasoning: Detailed industry critique of Meta's spatial computing efforts, cites internal sources, identifies cultural issues (executives lacking 3D thinking), specific failures. Valuable insider perspective.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer critiques Meta's VR strategy: Super Bowl promo failure, lack of games on Ray-Ban display glasses, internal culture problems with '2D thinkers'

For instance:

1. They threw a Super Bowl promotion but couldn't get more than 15,000 people into the concert they were advertising.

2. They failed to provide the right content for the hardware. In a lot of ways, you're right‚Äîthey needed a good AAA game.

This is actually something that bums me out about Meta's Ray-Ban smart glasses (the ones with the display). There's only one video game on them! It's like, you guys spent how many billions of dollars and you only got one video game?

You went too far the other way. You should have had a whole bunch of casual titles, like Angry Birds and Words with Friends. Something is just wrong with this team.

I hear from people inside and outside that it's a really bad culture in terms of getting people to work on a very innovative product and have big breakthroughs. A lot of the blame goes straight to Zuckerberg.

The truth is, most of the executives at Meta joined the company when they were very young. At that time, 3D computing didn't exist, so there are a lot of "2D thinkers" who struggle to get into spatial computing. I've heard that from many people both inside the team and out.

It's a tough situation. It's just going to take more time for this whole field to mature to a place where consumers see a huge amount of value in wearing a pair of glasses that have a lot of technology in them.

items.title: @SpatialBiggs Well, we'll see. Over the next few years, we'll see new devices and new approaches to ...
items.content:
@SpatialBiggs Well, we'll see. Over the next few years, we'll see new devices and new approaches to this whole virtual reality thing. It won't look like what Zuckerberg has shown us so far‚Äîat least not in my mind.

There are so many breakthroughs in Gaussian splat technology, for instance, that I would expect the next iteration to be much more photorealistic, much more interactable, and much cheaper to create due to AI. That'll fix a good chunk of the problems with creating VR apps and experiences.

items.content:
I've long heard that Apple is working on this kind of technology, but this is the first time I've seen a patent on it. Very interesting!

This would dramatically help them adjust to people like me who need corrective lenses. It also has a major advantage in that some people's eyes actually change every day (that's coming from their own research).

Their own research also found that a good percentage of people actually have the wrong corrective lenses in their eyeglasses, either because their eyes have changed, the optometrist messed up, or the process didn't work. This technology helps fix those people's problems as well. 

I don't expect glasses in 2027 to have this kind of technology, but I assume we'll see it over the next few years. But who knows?

@ChibiChaddeus There shouldn't be many because these are smarter apps. The store can also hide those that don't get engagement, or don't get downloaded or used, so I'm not too worried about having a lot of low-usage apps. As long as they remain pretty interesting (and they are), it should be fine.

I think this is a great company. If I had money, I would be trying to invest.

items.title: I just lived through my worst nightmare in a decade. X offered me the opportunity to join the Creato...
items.content:
I just lived through my worst nightmare in a decade. X offered me the opportunity to join the Creator program. To do that, I had to connect my Stripe account to X.

I do all my online business using Stripe, just so you understand the situation better.

So, I connected my Stripe account to X, and THIS DEACTIVATED MY MAIN BUSINESS ACCOUNT.

I couldn't sign in with my username and password: Stripe wouldn't accept the Authenticator app's code.

ChapterPal started rejecting subscriptions. The error message was that the user doesn't exist.

I reached out to Stripe support over chat, and the first associate who assisted me said he sees only my X account, that Stripe is nothing but a payment processor, so he doesn't understand what online business I just lost am I talking about, and I must now deal with X.

The X account on Stripe was empty.

So, I had to say something like, "Please understand that my entire online business was just erased. What do I say to my customers?"

After this, he transferred me to a different person while I already started to think about what kind of failure I will look like when I announce to my customers that their subscriptions are gone.

Long story short, I managed to find the account ID for my main account in my browser history, and this other associate managed to locate it in the system. Without knowing this account ID, they saw nothing except the empty X account.

They said the account was just there, up and running, but I know it wasn't because ChapterPal returned this error message. Then magically, it started to work again.

The moral of the story: Your online business is with you until the very first glitch in a database you don't control. Luckily, Stripe seems to keep deleted accounts. I wasn't that lucky when Amazon deleted my Kindle Direct Publishing account three years ago, and I lost all my books and book revenue without the possibility to restore the account. Amazon didn't even recognize the account existed; it was wiped out from all their databases with dedication.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov shares nightmare experience where connecting Stripe to X Creator program deactivated his main business account, nearly losing his entire online business.
items.reasoning: Personal story about platform risk. Not AI-specific but relevant cautionary tale for AI creators.

@sebuzdugan I would expect it to be similar to how they manage the store. They have rules on what's allowed in their store, and so I would expect even independent apps built inside another app to have to follow the same rules.

But it's an interesting question because here you would have to be managing a third-party store in a way. It will also be interesting to see if they do crack down on these kinds of cases.

items.title:
From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren‚Äôt venues anymore‚Äît...
items.content:
From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren‚Äôt venues anymore‚Äîthey‚Äôre living networks.

In my latest article I explore this together with @TMobileBusiness as a partner to unpack how it works.

What‚Äôs changing (fast):

‚Üí Connectivity = infrastructure. Ticketing, POS, broadcast, and crowd flow ride one wireless fabric. Less friction, faster ops, happier fans.

‚Üí Broadcast explodes in perspectives. More angles, less latency, interactive feeds you can steer.

‚Üí One network, many workloads. Dynamic bandwidth for what matters now‚Äîgate surges, replay reviews, merch spikes. 

‚Üí Partnerships accelerate breakthroughs. Ref-cams, AR graphics, on-body antennas‚Äînone of these ships without tight cross-team engineering.

Check out the full article: https://t.co/wrx6ctxUzd

Cc: @EvanKirstel | @Chels_LA | @antgrasso | @HaroldSinnott |

items.title:
I learn more from one real-world case study than from 10 textbooks.

There's something about seeing ...
items.content:
I learn more from one real-world case study than from 10 textbooks.

There's something about seeing how someone actually solved a problem that makes the lesson stick.

Constraints, tradeoffs, the things that break, and those that work.

I built my entire AI/ML Engineering program that way: A group of stories from the field, each one teaching an important lesson.

Every session walks through specific problems I've encountered building production systems.

I try to avoid as much theory as possible.

Instead, I focus on giving students the same blueprint I've used for all my projects over the last 30 years.

The next cohort starts February 2, 2026.

You can join at https://t.co/iZifcK7n47.

items.title: @wiseimhotep The Oura Ring seems to be the most useful for body tracking so far, though I haven't re...
items.content:
@wiseimhotep The Oura Ring seems to be the most useful for body tracking so far, though I haven't really decided yet. I bought several different trackers to compare them.

I like the idea of the Pebble because it doesn't need to be charged for a couple of years (we'll see if that actually proves true), but I don't know how useful it really is. My plan is to get some real-world experience by wearing each of them for a month to see which one:
1. Gives me the most useful data
2. Works the best overall

I have an Oura Ring right now, and it's pretty good.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer comparing body trackers: Oura Ring vs Pebble, planning month-long testing of each
items.reasoning: Health tech/wearables comparison, mentions Pebble's 2-year battery claim. Personal testing methodology.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer comparing body trackers: Oura Ring vs Pebble, planning month-long testing of each
items.content_html:

items.title:
Most companies lose millions of dollars because they don't listen to customers.

But it's not becaus...
items.content:
Most companies lose millions of dollars because they don't listen to customers.

But it's not because they don't know better.

It's just that getting feedback at scale is extremely expensive.

Microsoft used to spend $150,000+ on customer interviews to test Copilot.

Now they can do the same in 1-3 days at a fraction of the cost.

They've already run 100+ studies using Listen Labs.

The platform turns customer research from a slow, expensive bottleneck into something teams can do continuously.

Listen Labs makes getting customer feedback:

‚Ä¢ Fast
‚Ä¢ Scalable
‚Ä¢ Affordable

If you are building a product and want to interview real people anywhere in the world, you can now get answers in hours, not months.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Continuation of Listen Labs promotion highlighting Microsoft's use for Copilot testing and cost savings
items.reasoning: Promotional content thread continuation, though contains interesting data point about Microsoft Copilot testing costs

Listen Labs makes getting customer feedback:

If you are building a product and want to interview real people anywhere in the world, you can now get answers in hours, not months.

items.title: @JoshWalkos It's real easy. Put all my lists into X Pro and watch them live and you very quickly see...

@JoshWalkos It's real easy. Put all my lists into X Pro and watch them live and you very quickly see the problem. There is way way too much content. (I have the most complete lists of tech industry here on X: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ). 

And I have 550,000 followers and, yeah, it's a problem getting reach. 

That said, my feed is getting amazing lately, and will just get better over time. 

Lists show EVERYTHING with no filtering. Following feed does too. 

Urge your followers to follow you on lists. I've been trying to get you all to use lists for years because they let you see everything.

items.content: RE: https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/115737483111161917I have to admit, the performance of a Chromium-based browser compared to Firefox is abysmal. I don't have that many tabs but it lags a lot and the browser constantly puts tabs in hibernation to save memory--something I've never needed with Firefox. So all of you Chrome users live like this? No wonder RAM is in high demand.

items.title: @LexSokolin @stanine Well, jobs come from rich people investing in companies. There certainly won't ...
items.content: @LexSokolin @stanine Well, jobs come from rich people investing in companies. There certainly won't be jobs if we chase all the rich people and their companies out of California.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Political commentary about jobs, rich people, and California economy
items.reasoning: Off-topic political discussion unrelated to AI/ML
items.summary_html: Political commentary about jobs, rich people, and California economy
items.content_html: @LexSokolin @stanine Well, jobs come from rich people investing in companies. There certainly won't be jobs if we chase all the rich people and their companies out of California.

items.title: @stanine It's awful. The population hates the separation between rich and poor people, and they want...
items.content:
@stanine It's awful. The population hates the separation between rich and poor people, and they want to lash out. However, this is going to cause the poor people many more problems, because when the rich people leave, the jobs leave. 

If you don't have jobs, you don't have anything in your state. It doesn't matter how good the weather is or how nice the environment is here; if you don't have jobs, the economy starts falling apart. We're chasing away too many jobs in California. We need a new attitude to bring new jobs and new rich people to the state and get them to invest in the people of California.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Extended commentary on California wealth inequality and job flight
items.reasoning: Off-topic political/economic commentary, high engagement but not AI-relevant
items.summary_html: Extended commentary on California wealth inequality and job flight
items.content_html:
@stanine It's awful. The population hates the separation between rich and poor people, and they want to lash out. However, this is going to cause the poor people many more problems, because when the rich people leave, the jobs leave.

If you don't have jobs, you don't have anything in your state. It doesn't matter how good the weather is or how nice the environment is here; if you don't have jobs, the economy starts falling apart. We're chasing away too many jobs in California. We need a new attitude to bring new jobs and new rich people to the state and get them to invest in the people of California.

items.title:
aw bummer, my local wood guy retired and moved back east

during the cold months, he'd drive into ea...
items.content:
aw bummer, my local wood guy retired and moved back east

during the cold months, he'd drive into eastern WA to pick up dried logs, chop em up in his garage, deliver during the week day, and have people like me pick up on the weekends

once it got warm, he'd close up shop, and spend the summer on his boat

i always looked forward to chatting with him, he liked helping load the car

he will be missed
items.author: @yoheinakajima
items.summary: yoheinakajima sharing personal story about his local wood supplier retiring and moving
items.reasoning: Personal/off-topic, not AI related
